metadata.purpose: Comprehensive standards reference with topic-level detail for curriculum generation
sources: Common Core State Standards for Mathematics
Common Core State Standards for ELA
Research on student misconceptions and learning progressions

ratios_proportional_relationships.cluster: Understand ratio concepts and use ratio reasoning

6.RP.A.1.description: Understand the concept of a ratio and use ratio language to describe a ratio relationship between two quantities
common_misconceptions: Adding instead of multiplying to find equivalent ratios
Treating ratio as subtraction (difference between quantities)
intervention_strategies: Use tape diagrams to show ratio relationships visually
Explicitly contrast ratio notation with fraction notation

6.RP.A.2.description: Understand the concept of a unit rate a/b associated with a ratio a:b with b ≠ 0
common_misconceptions: Dividing in wrong order (b/a instead of a/b)
intervention_strategies: Start with money contexts ($X per item)

6.RP.A.3.description: Use ratio and rate reasoning to solve real-world problems

substandards.6.RP.A.3a: Make tables of equivalent ratios, find missing values, plot on coordinate plane
substandards.6.RP.A.3b: Solve unit rate problems (unit pricing, constant speed)
substandards.6.RP.A.3c: Find percent of quantity as rate per 100
substandards.6.RP.A.3d: Use ratio reasoning to convert measurement units

common_misconceptions: Adding same number to both parts of ratio to scale
intervention_strategies: Build tables systematically row by row

number_system.cluster_a: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division
number_system.cluster_c: Apply and extend previous understandings of numbers to rational numbers

6.NS.A.1.description: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, solve word problems with fraction division
common_misconceptions: Not knowing when to use fraction division in word problems

6.NS.B.2.description: Fluently divide multi-digit numbers using standard algorithm

6.NS.B.3.description: Fluently add, subtract, multiply, divide multi-digit decimals
common_misconceptions: Not aligning decimal points for addition/subtraction
Counting decimal places incorrectly in multiplication

6.NS.B.4.description: Find GCF and LCM, use distributive property

6.NS.C.5.description: Understand positive and negative numbers in real-world contexts
common_misconceptions: Negative numbers are 'nothing' or don't exist

6.NS.C.6.description: Understand rational number as point on number line

substandards.6.NS.C.6a: Recognize opposite signs of numbers as on opposite sides of 0
substandards.6.NS.C.6b: Understand signs of coordinates in quadrants
substandards.6.NS.C.6c: Find and position rational numbers on horizontal/vertical number lines

6.NS.C.7.description: Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers

6.NS.C.8.description: Solve problems by graphing points in all four quadrants

expressions_equations.cluster_a: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions
expressions_equations.cluster_b: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities

6.EE.A.1.description: Write and evaluate numerical expressions involving whole-number exponents
common_misconceptions: Adding exponents when multiplying base by exponent

6.EE.A.2.description: Write, read, evaluate expressions with variables

substandards.6.EE.A.2b: Identify parts of expression (term, factor, coefficient)

common_misconceptions: Variable means one specific unknown only

6.EE.A.3.description: Apply properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions

6.EE.A.4.description: Identify when two expressions are equivalent
common_misconceptions: Expressions must look the same to be equivalent

6.EE.B.5.description: Understand solving equation/inequality as finding values that make it true

6.EE.B.6.description: Use variables to represent numbers in expressions

6.EE.B.7.description: Solve real-world problems with equations x + p = q and px = q

6.EE.B.8.description: Write and represent inequalities, recognize infinite solutions

6.EE.C.9.description: Use variables for dependent and independent quantities, analyze relationships

geometry.cluster: Solve real-world problems involving area, surface area, and volume

6.G.A.1.description: Find area of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons by composing/decomposing
common_misconceptions: Using slant height instead of perpendicular height for triangles

6.G.A.2.description: Find volume of right rectangular prism with fractional edge lengths

6.G.A.3.description: Draw polygons in coordinate plane given vertices

6.G.A.4.description: Represent 3D figures using nets, find surface area

standards.6.SP.A.2: Understand data set has distribution described by center, spread, shape
standards.6.SP.A.3: Recognize measures of center and variability summarize data
standards.6.SP.B.4: Display data in plots (dot plots, histograms, box plots)
standards.6.SP.B.5: Summarize data sets in relation to context

ratios_proportional_relationships.cluster: Analyze proportional relationships and use them to solve problems

7.RP.A.1.description: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions
common_misconceptions: Not recognizing fraction ÷ fraction as unit rate

substandards.7.RP.A.2a: Decide if two quantities are proportionally related
substandards.7.RP.A.2b: Identify constant of proportionality (unit rate) in tables, graphs, equations, diagrams, verbal descriptions
substandards.7.RP.A.2d: Explain meaning of points on graph of proportional relationship

common_misconceptions: Graphs that pass near origin are proportional
Constant rate of change = proportional (ignoring y-intercept)
intervention_strategies: Use real contexts (direct variation vs initial fee + rate)

7.RP.A.3.description: Use proportional relationships to solve multistep ratio and percent problems

number_system.cluster: Apply and extend operations with rational numbers

7.NS.A.1.description: Apply and extend addition and subtraction to rational numbers

substandards.7.NS.A.1a: Describe situations where opposite quantities combine to 0
substandards.7.NS.A.1b: Understand p + q as distance |q| from p
substandards.7.NS.A.1c: Understand subtraction as adding additive inverse
substandards.7.NS.A.1d: Apply properties of operations to add/subtract rational numbers

7.NS.A.2.description: Apply and extend multiplication and division to rational numbers

substandards.7.NS.A.2d: Convert rational numbers to decimals, know terminating/repeating

7.NS.A.3.description: Solve real-world problems with all four operations on rational numbers

expressions_equations.cluster_a: Use properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions
expressions_equations.cluster_b: Solve real-life and mathematical problems using numerical and algebraic expressions and equations

7.EE.A.1.description: Apply properties to add, subtract, factor, expand linear expressions with rational coefficients

7.EE.A.2.description: Understand rewriting expressions shows relationships (e.g., a + 0.05a = 1.05a)
common_misconceptions: Percent increase as addition vs multiplication

7.EE.B.3.description: Solve multistep real-world problems with positive and negative rationals

7.EE.B.4.description: Use variables to represent quantities and construct equations/inequalities

substandards.7.EE.B.4a: Solve problems leading to equations px + q = r and p(x + q) = r
substandards.7.EE.B.4b: Solve problems leading to inequalities px + q > r or px + q < r

common_misconceptions: Inverse operation errors with multiple steps
Inequality sign flip with negative division

standards.7.G.A.1: Solve problems with scale drawings, compute lengths and areas
standards.7.G.A.2: Draw shapes with given conditions (triangles from three measures)
standards.7.G.B.4: Know and use formulas for area and circumference of circles
standards.7.G.B.5: Use angle relationships to solve for unknown angles
standards.7.G.B.6: Solve real-world problems with area, volume, surface area

standards.7.SP.A.1: Understand statistics from random sample represent population
standards.7.SP.A.2: Use data from random sample to draw inferences about population
standards.7.SP.B.3: Assess visual overlap of two numerical data distributions
standards.7.SP.B.4: Use measures of center and variability to compare populations

8.NS.A.1.description: Know numbers that are not rational are irrational; understand every number has decimal expansion

8.NS.A.2.description: Use rational approximations of irrational numbers to compare and locate on number line

expressions_equations.cluster_a: Work with radicals and integer exponents
expressions_equations.cluster_b: Understand connections between proportional relationships, lines, and linear equations
expressions_equations.cluster_c: Analyze and solve linear equations and pairs of simultaneous linear equations

8.EE.A.1.description: Know and apply properties of integer exponents

8.EE.A.2.description: Use square root and cube root symbols; evaluate perfect squares/cubes; know √2 is irrational

8.EE.A.3.description: Use numbers in scientific notation to estimate very large/small quantities

8.EE.A.4.description: Perform operations with numbers in scientific notation

8.EE.B.5.description: Graph proportional relationships; interpret unit rate as slope; compare representations

8.EE.B.6.description: Use similar triangles to explain slope constancy; derive y = mx and y = mx + b

8.EE.C.7.description: Solve linear equations in one variable

substandards.8.EE.C.7a: Give examples of equations with one, infinite, or no solutions
substandards.8.EE.C.7b: Solve equations with rational coefficients, distribution, combining like terms

common_misconceptions: Variables on both sides means no solution
All equations have exactly one solution

8.EE.C.8.description: Analyze and solve pairs of simultaneous linear equations

substandards.8.EE.C.8b: Solve systems algebraically and estimate graphically

8.F.A.1.description: Understand function as rule assigning exactly one output to each input
common_misconceptions: x can have multiple y values

8.F.A.2.description: Compare properties of functions represented differently (algebraically, graphically, tables, verbal)
common_misconceptions: Not recognizing same function in different forms

8.F.A.3.description: Interpret y = mx + b as linear; give examples of non-linear functions

8.F.B.4.description: Construct function to model linear relationship; determine rate of change and initial value
common_misconceptions: Rate of change vs y-intercept confusion
Starting value = first y-value in table

8.F.B.5.description: Describe qualitative functional relationship from graph; sketch from verbal description

standards.8.G.A.1: Verify properties of rotations, reflections, translations
standards.8.G.A.2: Understand congruence through sequences of transformations
standards.8.G.A.3: Describe effect of dilations, translations, rotations, reflections on 2D figures using coordinates
standards.8.G.A.4: Understand similarity through sequences of transformations
standards.8.G.A.5: Use informal arguments for angle relationships
standards.8.G.B.6: Explain Pythagorean theorem proof and its converse
standards.8.G.B.7: Apply Pythagorean theorem for unknown side lengths
standards.8.G.B.8: Apply Pythagorean theorem to find distance between points
standards.8.G.C.9: Know formulas for volumes of cones, cylinders, spheres

standards.8.SP.A.1: Construct and interpret scatter plots for bivariate data
standards.8.SP.A.2: Know that straight lines model relationships with linear association
standards.8.SP.A.3: Use equation of linear model to solve problems; interpret slope and intercept
standards.8.SP.A.4: Understand patterns of association in bivariate categorical data using two-way tables

ratios_to_proportions_to_linear.grade_6: Ratio concepts, unit rates, equivalent ratios, percent as rate per 100
ratios_to_proportions_to_linear.grade_7: Proportional relationships, constant of proportionality, y = kx, multistep percent problems
ratios_to_proportions_to_linear.grade_8: Slope as rate of change, y = mx + b, comparing linear functions, systems of equations

operations_to_expressions_to_equations.grade_6: Evaluate expressions, one-step equations (x + p = q, px = q), inequalities with infinite solutions
operations_to_expressions_to_equations.grade_7: Equivalent expressions with rationals, two-step equations (px + q = r), inequalities with graphs
operations_to_expressions_to_equations.grade_8: Multi-step equations with distribution, equations with no/infinite solutions, systems of linear equations

integers_to_rationals_to_reals.grade_6: Positive and negative integers, rational numbers on number line, absolute value
integers_to_rationals_to_reals.grade_7: Operations with all rational numbers, terminating and repeating decimals
integers_to_rationals_to_reals.grade_8: Irrational numbers, real number system, approximating irrationals

RL.6.1.description: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of explicit and inferential meaning
common_difficulties: Finding relevant evidence vs any evidence

RL.6.2.description: Determine theme or central idea and how it develops through details; summarize without opinions
common_difficulties: Theme as one word vs statement
intervention_strategies: Summary templates that exclude opinion language

RL.6.3.description: Describe how plot unfolds and how characters respond/change toward resolution
common_difficulties: Not connecting character change to plot

integration_knowledge.RL.6.9: Compare/contrast texts in different forms/genres on similar themes

range_complexity.RL.6.10: Read and comprehend literature in grades 6-8 complexity band proficiently, with scaffolding at high end

RI.6.1.description: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of explicit and inferential meaning

RI.6.2.description: Determine central idea and how conveyed through details; summarize without opinions

RI.6.3.description: Analyze how key individual, event, or idea is introduced, illustrated, and elaborated

craft_structure.RI.6.5: Analyze how sentence, paragraph, chapter, section fits into overall structure and contributes to ideas
craft_structure.RI.6.6: Determine author's point of view or purpose and explain how conveyed

integration_knowledge.RI.6.7: Integrate information from different media/formats to develop coherent understanding

integration_knowledge.RI.6.9: Compare/contrast one author's presentation with another's on same events

substandards.W.6.1b: Support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence from credible sources

substandards.W.6.3d: Use precise words, descriptive details, sensory language
substandards.W.6.3e: Provide conclusion that follows from narrated experiences

production_distribution.W.6.5: Develop and strengthen writing through planning, revising, editing, rewriting
production_distribution.W.6.6: Use technology to produce and publish writing; demonstrate keyboarding skills

research.W.6.7: Conduct short research projects to answer question, drawing on several sources
research.W.6.8: Gather relevant information from multiple sources; assess credibility; quote/paraphrase avoiding plagiarism
research.W.6.9: Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis

speaking_listening.SL.6.1: Engage in collaborative discussions with preparation, following rules, posing/responding to questions

language.L.6.6: Acquire and use grade-appropriate academic and domain-specific vocabulary

craft_structure.RL.7.6: Analyze how author develops and contrasts points of view of different characters/narrators

W.8.2.description: Write informative/explanatory texts including career documents

text_types.W.8.3: Write narratives with effective technique, relevant details, well-structured sequences

textual_evidence.grade_8: Cite evidence that most strongly supports

theme_analysis.grade_6: Determine theme and how conveyed through details
theme_analysis.grade_7: Analyze theme development over course of text
theme_analysis.grade_8: Analyze theme's relationship to characters, setting, plot

argument_evaluation.grade_7: Assess whether reasoning is sound and evidence relevant and sufficient
argument_evaluation.grade_8: Recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced

argumentative_writing.grade_6: Support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence
argumentative_writing.grade_8: Introduce claims precisely; distinguish from opposing claims

inference.description: Students struggle to make inferences, especially knowledge-based inferences requiring background knowledge integration
indicators: Can answer literal questions but not inferential
Doesn't connect prior knowledge to text

main_idea.description: Students confuse topic with main idea or cannot identify how details support central idea
indicators: Gives topic as main idea (single word)
Cannot distinguish key from supporting ideas
intervention_strategies: Main idea vs topic explicit instruction

vocabulary.description: Academic and domain-specific vocabulary gaps impede comprehension
intervention_strategies: Explicit vocabulary instruction with multiple exposures

text_structure.description: Students don't recognize how text is organized or use structure to aid comprehension

observable_signs: Does not understand foundational concepts from prior grades

ratios_proportions: Adds same number to scale ratios
equations: Variables represent one specific unknown only

support_strategies: Diagnostic assessment to identify specific gaps

observable_signs: Can perform procedures but cannot explain why
Some conceptual gaps from prior grades
Can sometimes transfer to new contexts
Can explain reasoning and justify solutions
Cannot identify theme or central idea
Can read grade-level text with some support
Comprehension is literal rather than inferential
Can cite evidence but not always relevant
Writing has some organization but weak development
Reads grade-level text fluently and with comprehension
Writing is organized with developed ideas
Can analyze author's craft and structure
Comprehends complex text beyond grade level

emerging.description: Students at this level typically progress quickly, learn to use English for immediate needs, and begin to understand and use academic language for the grade level
characteristics: Beginning to understand simple conversations and written texts
Relying heavily on context clues, visuals, and gestures
May have strong literacy in home language
Can engage in complex cognitive tasks with substantial language support
what_students_can_do: Respond to simple questions with single words or short phrases
Follow one-step directions with visual support
Identify key words in context with support
Participate in conversations using gestures and single words
Copy or label using word banks

expanding.description: Students at this level use their growing language skills in more advanced ways appropriate to their age and grade level
characteristics: Understanding more complex speech and texts
Producing longer sentences with some errors
Can discuss content with some scaffolding
what_students_can_do: Respond to questions with phrases and simple sentences
Participate in discussions using sentence frames

bridging.description: Students at this level can independently use a variety of high-level English language skills and participate in grade-level academic activities
characteristics: Understanding most spoken and written English
Producing complex sentences with minimal errors
Approaching fluency in reading and writing
what_students_can_do: Respond to questions with detailed explanations
Identify central ideas and analyze text
Lead and contribute to academic discussions
Write multi-paragraph texts with grade-level structure

visual_supports: Pictures and photographs for all key vocabulary
linguistic_supports: Sentence starters with heavy scaffolding (fill in one word)
Key vocabulary pre-taught with visuals and gestures
instructional_strategies: Chunked text with frequent comprehension checks
Partner work with more proficient peer
Allow drawing or pointing as response
Guided notes with blanks to fill

visual_supports: Reference charts available but not required
instructional_strategies: Extension activities connecting to prior knowledge

emerging: Number lines and place value charts
Key math vocabulary with pictures and symbols
expanding: Problem-solving frames (What do I know? What do I need to find?)
Explanation sentence starters ('First I... Then I... Because...')
Peer math talks with discussion frames
Sentence starters for each paragraph type
Peer writing conferences with guided questions

making_claims.expanding: Based on the evidence, I believe ___ because ___.
making_claims.bridging: The evidence suggests that ___, which demonstrates ___.

citing_evidence.expanding: According to the text, '___' shows that ___.
citing_evidence.bridging: The author states, '___,' which supports the idea that ___ by ___.

comparing.expanding: Both ___ and ___ share ___, but they differ in ___.
comparing.bridging: While ___ and ___ are similar in that ___, they diverge significantly regarding ___.

explaining_process.bridging: The process involves several steps: initially ___, followed by ___, and concluding with ___.

math_reasoning.expanding: I solved this by ___ because the problem asked me to ___.
math_reasoning.bridging: My approach was to ___, which is appropriate because ___. This strategy works here because ___.

agreeing_disagreeing.expanding: I agree with ___'s point that ___, and I would add ___.
agreeing_disagreeing.bridging: While I appreciate ___'s perspective on ___, I would argue that ___ because ___.

when_to_use: Jigsaw activities where all contribute unique pieces
Discussions where diverse perspectives are valued
heterogeneous_mixed_proficiency.benefits: ELs hear proficient language models; all students practice explaining and paraphrasing
heterogeneous_mixed_proficiency.cautions: Ensure ELs have meaningful roles, not just listening

when_to_use: When specific scaffolds are needed for all
homogeneous_same_proficiency.benefits: Tailored instruction to specific needs; comfortable risk-taking environment
homogeneous_same_proficiency.cautions: Avoid tracking; use flexibly based on skills, not fixed levels

strategic_partnering.emerging_with_expanding: Expanding student can model; emerging student has accessible peer support
strategic_partnering.expanding_with_bridging: Both can engage meaningfully; bridging student extends thinking
strategic_partnering.same_home_language: Can clarify concepts in L1 when needed; supports content comprehension

when_to_reduce_scaffolds: Student consistently succeeds with current support level
Student begins self-scaffolding (creating own graphic organizers)
Student can explain thinking without prompts
Student helps peers with similar tasks

when_to_use: Significant skill gaps requiring targeted intervention
Intensive remediation on specific prerequisite skills
Students with similar skill gaps or learning goals

homogeneous_by_skill.example: All students working on two-step equations

heterogeneous_mixed_ability.example: Mixed readiness levels working on open-ended problem

interest_based.example: Students who chose 'sports statistics' as context

content_design_considerations: Multiple entry points for different readiness levels
Meaningful work at all stations (not busywork)

eld_differentiation.instruction: When EL students are present, look up english_learner_support to determine appropriate scaffolds based on proficiency level
process: 1. Identify EL proficiency level(s) in the class (Emerging/Expanding/Bridging)
2. Look up scaffolding_strategies_by_level for that level
4. Include appropriate sentence_frames_by_task for the learning activity

scaffold_intensity.emerging: Include ALL scaffolds from the emerging list - visual supports, linguistic supports, adapted output expectations
scaffold_intensity.expanding: Include MOST scaffolds from expanding list, can offer emerging scaffolds as backup
scaffold_intensity.bridging: Include SOME scaffolds from bridging list, students should be moving toward independence

grouping_selection.instruction: Use group_vs_individual_instruction to determine appropriate instructional format based on user input

decision_tree.individual: Select when user indicates 1 student OR student needs intensive remediation OR sensitive/private content
decision_tree.small_group_homogeneous: Select when multiple students at same readiness level working on same skill gap
decision_tree.small_group_heterogeneous: Select when collaborative/discussion-based learning is goal OR peer modeling is beneficial
decision_tree.whole_class: Select when introducing new content to all OR building shared understanding

topic_lookup.instruction: Given a topic (e.g., 'ratios', 'theme analysis'), look up in topic_to_standards_mapping to find relevant standards, then retrieve detailed information from the grade-specific sections

differentiation.instruction: Use readiness_indicators_detailed to identify observable signs for each level, then apply corresponding support/extension strategies

below_level.approach: Check specific_gaps_by_topic for the topic being taught, address prerequisite gaps, use visual models, reduce complexity
below_level.content_adjustment: Focus on foundational concepts, more scaffolding, explicit instruction

above_level.approach: Use extension_strategies, connect across domains, increase complexity
above_level.content_adjustment: Add depth, open-ended problems, cross-grade content

prerequisite_check.instruction: Before teaching a standard, check the prerequisites field to identify what students should already know
prerequisite_check.remediation: If prerequisite gaps exist, provide targeted mini-lessons before main content

misconception_prevention.instruction: Review common_misconceptions for the topic before instruction; design lesson to explicitly address and prevent these
misconception_prevention.during_instruction: Use intervention_strategies proactively, not just reactively

learning_progression.instruction: Use learning_progressions sections to understand where a concept fits in the vertical sequence
learning_progression.credit_recovery: For students recovering credit, focus on current grade standards while filling prerequisite gaps from progression
